skill.name: device-management
skill.description: Manage device adoption and onboarding, maintain device inventory, and monitor device configurations across your UniFi network infrastructure.
skill.summary: Manage UniFi network devices with adoption tools, inventory tracking, and configuration monitoring.
skill.author: DataKnifeAI

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill is a legitimate UniFi Network MCP tool for device management. Flagged patterns are: SHA256 content hashes in metadata (mistaken for C2 indicators), Markdown code formatting in documentation (mistaken for shell execution), and environment variable examples for API authentication (standard documentation practice). No actual security risks identified.

high_findings.title: SHA256 content hashes flagged as C2/weak crypto
high_findings.description: Static scanner incorrectly identified SHA256 content hash strings in JSON metadata as C2 keywords and weak cryptographic algorithms. These are legitimate content hashes for file integrity verification.
high_findings.reasoning: The pattern matches hexadecimal hash strings which the scanner misidentified. Content hashes are standard metadata fields, not security threats.

high_findings.title: API credential examples flagged
high_findings.description: Static scanner flagged environment variable references in documentation as credential access risk.
high_findings.reasoning: Documentation includes example API key usage ($UNIFI_API_KEY, $UNIFI_BASE_URL) showing users how to configure credentials. This is standard practice for API integration skills and does not indicate credential exfiltration.

medium_findings.title: Markdown code formatting flagged as backtick execution
medium_findings.description: Static scanner identified backticks in SKILL.md as Ruby/shell command execution.
medium_findings.reasoning: Backticks are used for Markdown code formatting of tool names (get_pending_devices, get_network_devices, etc.). This is documentation syntax, not actual shell execution.

medium_findings.title: Network management terms flagged as reconnaissance
medium_findings.description: Static scanner flagged device management terminology as network reconnaissance.
medium_findings.reasoning: Terms like 'device adoption', 'monitor device configurations', and 'track pending devices' describe legitimate UniFi network management operations, not reconnaissance.

content.value_statement: Managing network devices manually is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automates device adoption, inventory tracking, and configuration monitoring for UniFi network infrastructure.
actual_capabilities: List all devices pending adoption in your UniFi network
Retrieve complete device inventory with specifications and status
Monitor controller health, version, and system status
Track device models, firmware versions, and configuration compliance
limitations: Requires a running UniFi Network MCP server with valid API credentials
Does not perform device adoption actions, only lists pending devices
Limited to read-only operations for device information retrieval
Site ID handling requires understanding of UniFi API conventions

use_cases.title: Network Administrator Device Onboarding
use_cases.description: Adopt new UniFi devices by first identifying all pending devices in the network, reviewing their details, and planning the adoption workflow across sites.

use_cases.title: IT Asset Management
use_cases.description: Maintain accurate device inventory by regularly querying the network for all adopted devices, their specifications, and configuration status.
use_cases.target_user: IT asset managers tracking network hardware

use_cases.title: Infrastructure Monitoring
use_cases.description: Monitor UniFi controller status and device health to identify outdated firmware, underperforming devices, or devices requiring attention.
use_cases.target_user: System engineers responsible for network uptime

best_practices: Adopt devices in logical groups by site or function to maintain organized network documentation
Regularly query the device inventory to track hardware age and plan upgrade cycles
Monitor controller firmware versions across devices to ensure consistent security updates
anti_patterns: Using this skill for real-time device adoption actions (read-only tool only)
Ignoring pending device alerts for extended periods (security risk)
Not documenting device purpose and location when adopting new hardware

faq.question: What credentials does this skill need?
faq.answer: This skill requires a UniFi Network MCP server configured with your UniFi credentials (UNIFI_API_KEY and UNIFI_BASE_URL). The skill communicates with your UniFi controller through the MCP server.

faq.question: Can this skill adopt devices?
faq.answer: No, this skill only lists pending devices and retrieves device information. The UniFi API requires separate tools for the actual adoption process.

faq.question: What is a site ID in UniFi?
faq.answer: UniFi sites separate network configurations into distinct groups. Your site ID may appear as an empty string in API responses, which represents the default site. Pass an empty string or 'default' when querying.

faq.question: How often should I check my device inventory?
faq.answer: For active networks, a weekly inventory check is recommended. This helps track new device additions, identify unexpected devices, and maintain accurate documentation.

faq.question: Does this skill work with UniFi Dream Machines?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill works with any UniFi Network installation that exposes the UniFi Network API, including UniFi Dream Machines, UniFi Cloud Keys, and UniFi Network servers.

faq.question: Can I export the device inventory to a file?
faq.answer: The skill provides structured output that you can copy to a document or spreadsheet. For automated exports, use the skill output as input to a file writing tool.
